intro: Anacampta longifolia, commonly known as the long-leaved anacampta, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant produces small, white to greenish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its leaves are long and slender, often with a fern-like appearance, and it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. Anacampta longifolia is often found in woodlands and along stream banks, where it contributes to the biodiversity of its habitat.
